author: By Miles Taylor and Christine Todd Whitman
title: We Are Republicans. There’s Only One Way to Save Our Party From Pro-Trump Extremists.
description: Moderates of both parties will need to build trust and cooperate in campaigning.
content: After Donald Trump’s defeat, there was a measure of hope among Republicans who opposed him that control of the party would be up for grabs, and that conservative pragmatists could take it back. But it’s become obvious that political extremists maintain a viselike grip on the national and state parties and the process for fielding and championing House and Senate candidates in next year’s elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Chucky Returns to Terrorize TV. His Creator Couldn’t Be Happier.
description: The gay filmmaker Don Mancini introduced the killer doll in 1988, and as the “Child’s Play” franchise has evolved, so has its queer sensibility.
content: There are many delightfully gruesome scenes that fans of the “Child’s Play” horror movies will devour in “Chucky,” the new show based on the popular franchise. The bloody death by dishwasher is a doozy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Diana Kipyokei of Kenya wins the women’s race of the Boston Marathon.
description: Kipyokei, 27, fended off the veteran Edna Kiplagat to capture her first victory in a major marathon.
content: Diana Kipyokei of Kenya won the Boston Marathon on Monday in her major marathon debut. At 27, her previous biggest victory was the Istanbul Marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Queen of the Internet
description: Meet Brooklyn Queen, a Gen Z artist and Renaissance woman.
content: Name: Brooklyn Queen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.6 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish colonial-style retreat in Chico, a Mediterranean-style house in San Francisco and a three-bedroom home in Los Angeles.
content: Chico, a city 90 miles north of Sacramento, is home to Bidwell Park, one of the largest public parks in the country. This house is less than half a block from the park and within walking distance of Sycamore Pool, a 1920s addition to the park that turned a section of Big Chico Creek into a concrete swimming pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Lawmakers Press to Rescue Afghan Relatives of U.S. Service Members
description: After a frenzied effort to evacuate Afghans who had worked with the U.S., members of Congress are now focusing on the stranded relatives of American troops.
content: WASHINGTON — More than a month after a frenzied U.S. effort to evacuate thousands facing retribution from the Taliban in Afghanistan, members of Congress are still quietly pushing the government to help extract a small group of stranded Afghans who are direct relatives of American military service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Grogan and Matthew Avignone
title: A Modernist Gem in Paris, Meticulously Restored
description: Since purchasing a 1920s townhouse by Robert Mallet-Stevens, the art and antiques dealer Éric Touchaleaume has been deeply faithful to the architect’s original vision.
content: ÉRIC TOUCHALEAUME WAS a teenager in the late 1960s when his cultured, peripatetic parents moved the family from Bordeaux to the Auteuil section of Paris’s posh 16th Arrondissement. Now in his 60s, the prominent dealer of mid-20th-century French design spent those early days exploring his new neighborhood on the edge of the Bois de Boulogne, winding past recherché centuries-old homes with bisque stone facades and quiet courtyards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: October Isn’t Just a Month Anymore. It’s a Whole Szn.
description: This year, there are more seasons than ever to celebrate.
content: October marks the start of myriad unofficial seasons: spooky season, pumpkin spice season, cuffing season, cozy season, hoodie season and, of course, decorative gourd season. (Or “szn,” for those inclined to abbreviate.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Southwest Airlines’ weekend was plagued by cancellations and delays.
description: Travelers flying Southwest Airlines over the weekend faced hundreds of canceled flights as well as frustrating delays, with the airline scrapping about a quarter of all its flights on Saturday and Sunday.
content: Travelers flying Southwest Airlines over the weekend faced hundreds of canceled flights as well as frustrating delays, with the airline scrapping about a quarter of all its flights on Saturday and Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: As E-Scooters and E-Bikes Proliferate, Safety Challenges Grow
description: A surge in electric-powered mobility devices during the pandemic is likely to become a lasting feature, transforming the New York City streetscape.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has upended many of the familiar routines that make up everyday urban life, bringing tectonic shifts in office culture, classroom learning and online shopping.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Merck applies for emergency authorization for what would be the first pill to treat Covid.
description: The company is seeking federal sign-off for the pill to be given to high-risk people sick with Covid. Tens of millions of Americans could be eligible.
content: Merck said on Monday that it had submitted an application to the Food and Drug Administration to authorize what would be the first antiviral pill to treat Covid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Hillary Clinton and Louise Penny Deliver a Page-Turner Part Sly, Part Sweet
description: “State of Terror” is a geopolitical thriller about the race to keep nuclear devices from being detonated in American cities.
content: It’s hard not to bring a heavy dose of armchair psychology to “State of Terror,” the surprising new geopolitical thriller by Hillary Rodham Clinton and Louise Penny. I say surprising because Penny is best known for writing gentler mysteries that plumb the delicate secrets of the heart and Clinton has never published a novel before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Who Really Controls Local Politics?
description: The strange case of Nithya Raman, the embattled Los Angeles City Councilwoman.
content: In November 2020, Nithya Raman, a 40-year-old former urban planner, unseated a well-funded fellow Democrat and thoroughly endorsed incumbent named David Ryu to win the Los Angeles City Council seat for Council District 4 (CD-4). It’s an amoeba-shaped area that encompasses the tony hills of Silver Lake, where Raman lives, sweeps down through the ultrawealthy avenues of Hancock Park, pushes out past the 18 high-rise apartment buildings of Park LaBrea, travels through working- and middle-class sections of the Los Feliz flats and Hollywood, runs up the Hollywood Hills and finally spills out into the suburb of Sherman Oaks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Sydney roars back to life as pubs and stores open after three months.
description: Australia’s largest city eased restrictions Monday after more than 100 days in lockdown.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — With excitement and caution, Sydney stepped out of lockdown Monday after more than 100 days of Delta-diminished existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: ‘This Drop Came So Quickly’: Shrinking Schools Add to Hong Kong Exodus
description: The Chinese territory is experiencing its biggest population drop in decades as residents flee political repression and a new “patriotic” curriculum.
content: HONG KONG — Long before the school year began, Chim Hon Ming, a primary school principal in Hong Kong, knew this year’s student body would be smaller. The city’s birthrate had already been falling, and families were increasingly frustrated by Hong Kong’s strict pandemic restrictions and the political turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘Let Them Talk’: Astros Spend a Rainy Day Discussing Allegations
description: Monday’s game was postponed because of poor weather, but comments by a Chicago reliever had Houston playing defense.
content: CHICAGO — Before Game 4 of the American League division series between the Chicago White Sox and the Houston Astros was postponed from Monday to Tuesday because of rain, Astros Manager Dusty Baker, a music aficionado, was listening to a blues classic. The lyrics, he said, were fitting when he was later asked about comments made Sunday night by White Sox reliever Ryan Tepera, who suggested that the Astros were still up to their sign-stealing ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: Moving to a Crown Heights Apartment Allowed Her to Nurture a Green Thumb
description: Taming the junglelike garden in Brooklyn has given her purpose — and a place to entertain.
content: Jaclyn Baird really wanted her desk to be a work space, but the plants have taken over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Brenda Wintrode and JoAnna Daemmrich
title: A Babysitter and a Band-Aid Wrapper: Inside the Submarine Spy Case
description: Jonathan and Diana Toebbe seemed like an ordinary suburban couple, but the F.B.I. said they were would-be spies — and sloppy ones.
content: WASHINGTON — On July 28, Diana Toebbe posted a Facebook message looking for a babysitter to take care of her children early on the coming Saturday morning for five to six hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: More Than 30 Countries Join U.S. Pledge to Slash Methane Emissions
description: Methane is the second-largest driver of global warming after carbon dioxide emissions. Scientists say the promised cuts could help avert the worst consequences of climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday announced that 32 countries had joined the United States in a pledge to reduce methane emissions, part of an effort to set new targets to slow global warming before a major United Nations climate summit in Glasgow next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: In Rolling Over Chiefs, Bills Encounter Little Resistance
description: An easy Buffalo victory left Kansas City with a losing record and a lot of questions about its defense.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Before Patrick Mahomes even saw the field for the Kansas City Chiefs as their starting quarterback three years ago, he saw their future. Ignoring the organization’s portfolio of postseason fiascos, its half-century of stepping on land mines, he assessed the Chiefs’ infrastructure — their inventive coaching staff, resourceful front office and nucleus of young talent — and forecast a dynasty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Mr. Joctober: Pederson’s Blast Was all the Offense Atlanta Needed
description: The Milwaukee Brewers tried, and failed to capitalize on a pair of early base runners. Joc Pederson, with a knack for coming through, wouldn’t know anything about that.
content: Only one division series this fall is truly a clash of the luckless. The Milwaukee Brewers have not reached the World Series in nearly four decades, and have never won a championship. Atlanta has gone 26 years without a title, and has not won a pennant in the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Chicken & Biscuits,’ a Sweet but Dated Comedic Recipe
description: Squabbling siblings, familiar stereotypes and a chorus of amens: A new play aims for the pleasures of Broadway’s traditional family sitcoms.
content: “Why we gotta wear black, huh? We already Black!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tess Thackara
title: The Artistic Aromas of Anicka Yi
description: The conceptual artist has taken over Tate Modern’s Turbine Hall in London with an odorous work to excite the senses.
content: Six years ago, the artist Anicka Yi created an exhibition on a theme that now feels eerily prescient: human fears of viral contagion. After an Ebola case was confirmed in New York, unsettling city life and causing months of anxiety, Yi set up tents at The Kitchen arts venue in Manhattan to display petri dishes containing bacteria she had gathered from 100 women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dottie Dodgion, a Standout Drummer in More Ways Than One, Dies at 91
description: At a time when a female jazz percussionist was a rarity, she played with Benny Goodman and went on to work with Marian McPartland and other big names.
content: Dottie Dodgion, one of the very few high-profile female drummers in the male-dominated jazz world of the 1950s and ’60s, died on Sept. 17 in a hospice center in Pacific Grove, Calif. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: There’s More Than One Way to Play Dead
description: The Senate is in a tizzy. Education is in a tizzy. Also, Democratic strategists.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, October is my favorite month. And now that the Senate has decided not to default on the national debt, really, what could be better?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden’s Proposal to Empower I.R.S. Rattles Banks and Their Customers
description: To help fund its new initiatives, the Biden administration wants banks to report more customer information. Account holders aren’t happy.
content: When the Biden administration looked for ways to pay for the president’s expansive social policy bill, it proposed raising revenue by cracking down on $7 trillion in unpaid taxes, mostly from wealthy Americans and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Bashar al-Assad Steps In From the Cold, but Syria Is Still Shattered
description: Arab countries are gradually restoring ties with Syria, but its president remains mired in crises he can’t escape.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For a man who has spent the last decade battling armed rebels, being shunned in international forums and watching a brutal civil war dismantle his economy, the past few weeks have been good to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: 2021-22 N.H.L. Season: What’s New and What’s Returning to Normal
description: Seattle gets the Kraken, Canadian fans return to the arena, regular divisions and cross-border travel are back, and N.H.L. players are headed to the Olympics.
content: The N.H.L. is looking forward to easing back into normalcy on the ice and in the stands. After two chaotic years (and two titles for the Tampa Bay Lightning), the league will be hoping to crown a champion next spring without unwelcome pandemic-related drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: Boosters Are Complicating Efforts to Persuade the Unvaccinated to Get Shots
description: The number of eligible people still weighing whether to get a Covid vaccine has sharply dwindled, leaving an unvaccinated population that is mostly hard-core refusers.
content: Vaccinated people have been burning up the phone lines at the community health center in rural Franklin, La., clamoring for the newly authorized Covid booster shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Evergrande’s creditors consider their options as more payment deadlines loom.
description: The Chinese real estate developer has three more payments due Monday on its dollar bonds, and offshore bondholders are beginning to worry.
content: Evergrande, the teetering Chinese real estate developer, has three more payments due Monday on its dollar bonds. It’s been about two weeks since the company, which has $300 billion in liabilities, missed a Sept. 23 bond payment, starting the clock on the 30-day grace period before it formally defaults.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon expands flexibility for some employees to work from home indefinitely.
description: The announcement was a further retreat from the rigid stance the tech giant had taken earlier this year.
content: Amazon told employees on Monday that it was loosening its plans to force workers to return to their offices, further retreating from a more rigid approach it had taken earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Netflix employee who criticized Dave Chappelle’s comedy special is among three suspended.
description: Netflix said in a statement that the transgender employee, Terra Field, was not suspended because of the tweets critical of Mr. Chappelle’s show.
content: Netflix recently suspended three employees, including a transgender employee who posted a Twitter thread last week criticizing a new Dave Chappelle stand-up special on the streaming service as being transphobic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Deb Haaland, the Interior secretary, runs to honor Indigenous Peoples’ Day.
description: Haaland, the first Native American cabinet secretary, ran the Boston Marathon as a tribute to the sacrifices of Indigenous people, she wrote.
content: Deb Haaland, President Biden’s secretary of the Interior, was among this year’s more recognizable amateur runners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: The Hand-Beaded Chanel Bag That Takes 120 Hours to Embroider
description: For the latest iteration of its 11.12 pocketbook, the house drew inspiration from its founder’s favorite flower, and from the savoir-faire of its artisans.
content: The origins of Chanel’s classic flap handbags can be traced back to February 1955, when the house’s founder, Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel, created her first pocketbook with a shoulder strap. Like most of her ideas, that purse, dubbed the 2.55 (to commemorate the month and year it was introduced), had feminist underpinnings: The strap allowed women to keep their hands free instead of clutching a handle. In 1983, Karl Lagerfeld, the label’s longtime creative director, subtly updated the 2.55, replacing the simple twist Mademoiselle clasp with interlocking C’s, and would go on to make other modifications. The reinterpreted bag was named the 11.12, evoking the internal style code of Lagerfeld’s medium-size version, the A01112. But while the shape of the purse has remained consistent through the decades, Chanel continues to iterate its embellishments, capitalizing on the house’s small specialist craft ateliers, called Métiers d’art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Maryann Plunkett Says Goodbye to Her Lives in Rhinebeck
description: She has portrayed three characters over the course of the 12 plays in Richard Nelson’s “Rhinebeck Panorama.” A decade later, it’s time to move on.
content: Talking with the actress Maryann Plunkett recently, it was hard to know, at times, whether she was speaking as herself or Barbara, Mary or Kate — the three characters she has played over the course of Richard Nelson’s “Rhinebeck Panorama” cycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Ephemeral Beauty of Night-Blooming Flowers
description: Plants that unfurl their petals only in darkness often condense the drama and poetry of their blossoming into one supercharged — and unpredictable — evening.
content: BY DAY, HYLOCEREUS undatus resists friendship. A climbing cactus native to Mexico and Central America but now thriving in regions tropical and temperate around the world, it can grow more than 30 feet tall, colonizing trees and rock walls with extended, fleshy stems, massed like the arms of an octopus. All year it sprawls, a spiked barricade — and then, one night, the flowers come. Starting around dusk (depending on where in the world you are, how warm the day, the ponderousness of clouds), the pale, waxy buds, which resemble elongated artichokes, start to open, the pink-tipped sepals peeling back millimeter by millimeter until, by midnight, the secret is told: the blossom announcing itself, so white it seems to glow, with skinny yellow streamers at its throat. Its life is a matter of hours; in the light of day, it retreats and shrivels, a ball gown turned to rags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: As Southwest Airlines tries to return to normal, some flight cancellations persist.
description: The airline and its pilots union denied that the cancellations were related to the company’s decision to require employees to be vaccinated against the coronavirus.
content: Southwest Airlines canceled several hundred flights on Monday as it worked to resolve the problems that led it to strike more than a quarter of its scheduled flights over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Rick Hoyt, who became a fixture in Boston while being pushed by his father, retires from the marathon.
description: Rick Hoyt, 59, cited his health as the reason he would no longer participate. His father, Dick, died in March.
content: If there has been one iconic image at the Boston Marathon over the years, it was Dick Hoyt pushing his son Rick in a wheelchair along the course route.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Was That a Ground-Rule Double or an Automatic Double?
description: A hit by Kevin Kiermaier in Tampa Bay’s loss to Boston in Game 3 of their division series caused confusion among fans in more ways than one.
content: As people debated if Kevin Kiermaier’s double in the 13th inning of Sunday’s division series game between the Tampa Bay Rays and the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park was called correctly by the umpires (it was), a second debate emerged about what to call such a hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Is the Race to the Bottom Over?
description: To crack down on tax havens, nations have agreed on a plan for a global minimum tax of 15 percent.
content: Economics professors like to stage a fun competition with their students to introduce them to game theory. It goes like this:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: At Wellesley, the students offer screams, but no smooches, as the marathon returns.
description: Cheers, signs and kisses are signatures at the Scream Tunnel that marks the halfway point of the race. But this year, because of the pandemic, organizers asked students to keep their mouths to themselves.
content: The screams can be heard from blocks away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: A W.H.O. panel recommends additional vaccine doses for immunocompromised people.
description: Officials noted that the shots were not boosters, but meant to shore up the immune response in people for whom the one- or two-dose course of treatment was insufficient.
content: Severely or moderately immunocompromised people who have been vaccinated should be offered an additional dose of the seven coronavirus vaccines the World Health Organization has authorized, an advisory committee recommended on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: U.S. Suffers First Defeat in World Cup Qualifying
description: A listless performance by a shuffled lineup in a defeat at Panama cost the Americans some valuable momentum.
content: Continuing the good vibes from one performance to the next can be tough, it turns out, when you switch out all of your top performers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht
title: One in five of England’s most critically ill Covid patients are unvaccinated pregnant women, a study finds.
description: Health officials say the risks from getting Covid-19 are far greater than any potential side effects from the vaccine.
content: Unvaccinated pregnant women make up nearly 20 percent of the most critically ill Covid-19 patients in England, according to data released by the National Health Service on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Chicago’s Crowd, and Its Offense, Comes Alive Against the Astros
description: An emotional game staved off elimination for the White Sox, but not without some controversy in calls on the field and comments after the game.
content: CHICAGO — The first two of games of this American League division series between the Houston Astros and the Chicago White Sox were decidedly one-sided. The Astros outscored their opponent by a combined 15-5 and came into Sunday needing only one more victory to advance to their fifth straight A.L. Championship Series. The White Sox, winners of a weaker division, looked overmatched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom, Jonah E. Bromwich and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Inside Rikers: Dysfunction, Lawlessness and Detainees in Control
description: With a staffing emergency disrupting the basic functions of the jail system, detainees have had free rein inside.
content: When a detainee decided to hijack a bus inside the Rikers Island jail complex, little was in place to stop him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Danica Patrick returns to racing. On foot.
description: Patrick, who retired in 2018, is running in bib number 500, a nod by race organizers to her trailblazing accomplishments at the Indianapolis 500 and Daytona 500.
content: Danica Patrick is no stranger to racing, but on Monday she will be competing in a different kind of race as she runs her first marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Superman Comes Out, as DC Comics Ushers In a New Man of Steel
description: The new Superman, the son of Clark Kent and Lois Lane, is concerned about the environment, does not shy away from politics and will soon begin a romantic relationship with a male friend.
content: Up, up and out of the closet!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: A Tough (Correct) Call and a Walk-Off Homer Have the Rays on the Brink
description: A confusing play in extra innings highlighted an unusual rule, but Boston took a commanding series lead over Tampa Bay on Christian Vazquez’s two-run blast.
content: BOSTON — Christian Vazquez’s night began on the bench. It ended with a triumphant jog around the bases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Samantha Bee Talks Marjorie Taylor Greene and the Trumps
description: The comedian and advocate talks about politics, Covid-19 and life after covering the former president.
content: The 45th president may have been ripe material for (dark) comedy, but Samantha Bee sure does not miss him. After covering Donald Trump for six seasons on her late night show “Full Frontal With Samantha Bee,” she says, “Comedy is better without him. Just the world in general, — the globe — is better without him.” She now has airtime to double down her coverage of other challenges like climate change and the affront to voting and abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Johnny Diaz
title: Police Officer Drags Man by Hair From Car. ‘I’m Paraplegic,’ He Protests.
description: Body camera footage released by the police in Dayton, Ohio, showed the encounter with Clifford Owensby, who has filed a complaint with the N.A.A.C.P.
content: A Black man who was pulled from a car by police officers while yelling “I’m paraplegic” filed a complaint with the N.A.A.C.P., the organization said, as the police in Dayton, Ohio, said they were investigating what had happened during the stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Major marathons return in the U.S., with Chicago leading the way.
description: Ruth Chepngetich of Kenya and Seifi Tura of Ethiopia won the first major marathon in the U.S. in nearly two years.
content: After waiting nearly two years for America’s three major marathons to return, runners and fans alike were greeted with back-to-back spectacles, with Chicago leading the way on Sunday and Boston picking up the pace on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Fight or Flight
description: Southwest’s weekend disruptions fueled opposition to corporate vaccine mandates.
content: Southwest Airlines canceled more than 1,000 flights yesterday, and just over 800 on Saturday, wreaking havoc on weekend travel plans for thousands of passengers. The cancellations accounted for around a quarter of the airline’s scheduled flights this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Missing Apostrophe in Facebook Post Lands a Man in Defamation Court
description: An Australian man claimed a real estate agent did not pay its “employees” retirement funds. The lack of a punctuation mark may cost him thousands.
content: A missing apostrophe in a Facebook post could cost a real estate agent in Australia tens of thousands of dollars after a court ruled a defamation case against him could proceed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: After Years of Sexual Abuse Allegations, How Did This Doctor Keep Working?
description: Hospital staff members looked the other way while Ricardo Cruciani addicted vulnerable women to pain medications and assaulted them, according to a new lawsuit.
content: All Tanisha Johnson wanted was for the pain to go away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Here’s how to watch the Boston Marathon.
description: After being delayed by 18 months because of the pandemic, the Boston Marathon is back this year, marking its 125th anniversary.
content: After being delayed by 18 months because of the pandemic, the Boston Marathon is back this year, marking its 125th anniversary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Mayim Bialik Wants the ‘Jeopardy!’ Job. Is She ‘Neutral’ Enough?
description: Alex Trebek projected impartiality. Bialik has questioned vaccines, endorsed a disputed brain supplement and weighed in on hot-button issues.
content: After the succession debacle at “Jeopardy!” turned one of television’s most respected game shows into a punchline on late-night talk shows and at the Emmy Awards, Mayim Bialik took over as a temporary host this season with a simple goal: not to draw too much attention to herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Roberta Gibb broke barriers in the Boston Marathon. Now there’s a statue of her feat.
description: A sculpture of Gibb was unveiled near the starting line more than 55 years after she became the first woman to complete the Boston Marathon.
content: In 1966, Roberta Gibb became the first woman to complete the Boston Marathon at a time when women were prohibited from doing so because they were considered “physiologically incapable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: In Iraq Election, Shiite Cleric Who Fought U.S. Strengthens Power
description: Results showed the party of Muqtada al-Sadr making the biggest gains in a vote that could help shape Iraq’s direction and its relationship with both the United States and Iran.
content: BAGHDAD — Followers of a Shiite cleric whose fighters battled U.S. forces during the occupation made the biggest gains in Iraq’s parliamentary election, strengthening his hand in determining whether the country drifts further out of the American orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: A Chicago Folk Hero Brings His Postseason Act to Boston
description: Kyle Schwarber’s mammoth blasts made him a fan favorite for the curse-breaking Cubs. For the Red Sox, he has picked up right where he left off.
content: BOSTON — Before Red Sox first baseman Kyle Schwarber cemented his status as a big-game performer, he was just a high school senior trying to impress a visiting college coach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Severe Weather Sweeps Across Southern Plains, Producing at Least Two Tornadoes
description: Fast-moving storms damaged parts of a town and at least one school in northeastern Oklahoma, while severe weather forced the Texas state fair to close early and delayed an N.F.L. game in Kansas City.
content: A band of severe weather moving across Oklahoma late Sunday and into Monday spawned at least two tornadoes and prompted a wave of warnings, a weather official said. There were no immediate reports of injuries or deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: echelon
description: This word has appeared in 54 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: “Freedom Day” in Sydney.
content: Sydney stepped out of lockdown Monday after more than 100 days: “Freedom Day,” with rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Benson Kipruto of Kenya wins the men’s race at the Boston Marathon.
description: Kipruto, 30, added a signature marathon victory to his résumé in the first Boston Marathon in more than a year.
content: Benson Kipruto won the men’s race Monday at the Boston Marathon, which was held for the first time since 2019, in an unfamiliar fall setting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: 40-Year-Old Cold Case of South Dakota Baby Ends With Conviction
description: Decades after a baby was found by the road, DNA testing led to criminal charges. On Friday, a woman entered an Alford plea in the case, accepting a guilty plea for manslaughter without admitting to the crime.
content: A South Dakota woman was convicted on Friday in the death of her newborn son, according to court documents, ending a cold case that began when the boy’s body was found near a cornfield four decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A missed turn may have cost Marcel Hug $50,000 in the men’s wheelchair race.
description: Hug dominated the event at the Boston Marathon, but he was just seconds shy of breaking his own course record and winning a bonus.
content: Marcel Hug of Switzerland won his fifth Boston Marathon wheelchair event on Monday, but a missed turn may have been costly for him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Boosters, Hong Kong, Boston Marathon: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Loans Will Be the Key to Banks’ Future Fortunes
description: The big banks are expected to benefit from increased consumer spending when they report earnings this week. Where they go from here will depend greatly on lending to households and businesses.
content: As investors brace for underwhelming earnings reports across much of the business world, the country’s biggest banks are expected to report solid profits this week, thanks to the central role they play in the reopening economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Haigney
title: Underground Museum Looks to Philadelphia Curator
description: Meg Onli will join the Los Angeles museum as director and curator, co-leading with Cristina Pacheco. Onli’s priority: spending time in Arlington Heights.
content: Meg Onli will join the Underground Museum in Los Angeles as director and curator, co-leading the museum with director and chief operations officer Cristina Pacheco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How One San Francisco Street Survived the Pandemic
description: Clement Street in the Richmond District may be a window into neighborhoods of the future.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — In the space of just three blocks, hundreds of people packed in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Bernard Tapie, French Tycoon, Actor and Politician, Dies at 78
description: His larger-than-life career, flamboyant personality and ongoing legal struggles made him one of the best-known personalities in France.
content: PARIS — Bernard Tapie, a swaggering French businessman who lurched throughout his life from wild success to humiliation, knowing everything from high political office to the prison cell, died on Oct. 3 in Paris. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: British push to toughen legislation against misogyny.
content: Amid a national outcry in Britain over gender-based crimes, including the murder of Sarah Everard by a London police officer, the public discourse has turned to a new question: Should misogyny be considered a hate crime?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Secrets of Pizza Perfection
description: The latest release from Modernist Cuisine is a three-volume set dedicated to the fine art of pizza making.
content: Nobody can slice and dice a food topic, with vibrant photos along the way, like Nathan Myhrvold and his team at Modernist Cuisine. They have now tackled pizza. Are you ready for more than 1,000 recipes? They’re in the three massive volumes, plus a kitchen primer, covering history, science, equipment, recipes, trivia, technical details, ingredients, innovations and culture across the globe. They explain how to flavor fior di latte mozzarella, suggest what to do with leftover pizza and how to troubleshoot. In a first for the books, there is a chapter on where to find what the authors consider great pizza in more than 25 cities, in the United States and abroad, the result of visiting more than 250 pizzerias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Doing Economics as if Evidence Matters
description: A well-deserved Nobel reminds us why facts seem to have a liberal bias.
content: Nobel Memorial Prizes in economics are given for long-term research, not for economists’ role in current debates, so they don’t necessarily have much bearing on the political moment. You might expect the disconnect to be especially strong when the prize is given mainly for the development of new research methods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Bonbon With Benefits
description: Sales of these Jacques Torres bourbon bonbons come with a year’s membership in the Jacques Pépin Foundation.
content: These chocolates are the treat of the two Jacques. To benefit the Jacques Pépin Foundation, the chocolatier Jacques Torres has created bonbons draped in dark chocolate with a ganache filling spiked generously with Woodford Reserve bourbon, a favorite of Mr. Torres and a supporter of the foundation. The sale of each box of 12 includes a one-year membership in the Foundation at the commis level, which allows access to recipes and cooking videos with Mr. Pepin and other chefs. The chocolates can be ordered only from Oct. 12 through Nov. 12 and will be delivered in early December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: KKR’s co-chiefs, Henry Kravis and George Roberts, step down.
description: Joe Bae and Scott Nuttall are taking over as co-chief executives in a succession plan that was set in motion in 2017.
content: Henry Kravis and George Roberts, the private equity titans who founded KKR with Jerome Kohlberg Jr. in 1976, are handing over the keys. They defined the 1980s leverage buyout boom with the firm’s acquisition of RJR Nabisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: A New Cookbook by Indigenous People, for Indigenous People
description: A group of Indigenous chefs is releasing a virtual cookbook featuring digital issues, webinars and videos to reclaim narratives about Native foods.
content: The chiltepin is a tiny, powerfully spicy chile that’s the genetic grandparent of nearly every chile varietal cultivated in the United States. It’s a living emblem of how Indigenous ingredients formed the bedrock of American foodways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: A Nazi Legacy Haunts a Museum’s New Galleries
description: The Kunsthaus Zurich built an extension to display masterpieces from a private Swiss collection. But critics say the works are tainted by the source of their owner’s wealth.
content: ZURICH — With the opening of an imposing extension on Saturday, the Zurich Kunsthaus became Switzerland’s largest art museum. The vast new cube designed by the British architect David Chipperfield, opposite the original building on a central square, more than doubles the museum’s exhibition space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Indigenous Peoples’ Day, Explained
description: Many cities and states are observing the day. Here’s some of the history behind it.
content: President Biden has proclaimed Monday, Oct. 11, as Indigenous Peoples’ Day, becoming the first U.S. president to formally recognize the day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Rebuilding the Mystique of an Asphalt Sanctuary
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 11, 2021.
content: “It’s something that needs to be preserved. You treat Rucker Park like you treat Central Park, the Empire State Building, Ellis Island, Statue of Liberty.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Cutting Out Even a Little Salt Can Have Big Health Benefits
description: For many, reducing sodium in the diet even modestly can have an outsize impact on lowering blood pressure.
content: Sometimes, seemingly small changes in a health measurement can make a very large difference to people’s well-being. Such is the case with the effect on blood pressure of the essential nutrient sodium, the problematic half of the popular flavoring agent sodium chloride, commonly known as salt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Jim Tankersley
title: ‘We Suffer While You Debate’: Many Fear Being Left Behind as Democrats Trim Spending Bill
description: President Biden had an ambitious agenda to remake the economy. But under the duress of negotiations and Senate rules, he has shelved a series of proposals, some of them indefinitely.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress are curbing their ambitions for President Biden’s economic agenda, and Jennifer Mount, a home health care aide, worries that means she will not get the raise she needs to pay more than $3,000 in medical bills for blindness in one eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Anne Saxelby’s Legacy as a Champion of American Cheese
description: The cheesemonger, who sold strictly American-made cheeses, died over the weekend. She was 40.
content: Anne Saxelby, who championed American artisanal cheeses for more than 15 years, died on Saturday. She was 40 and had a heart condition. From her first minuscule stall for Saxelby Cheesemongers in the Essex Market on the Lower East Side, which she opened in 2006, to the more spacious counter in the Chelsea Market she moved to in 2017, she took the daring position of selling only American-made cheeses. She sought them out and helped cheese lovers and chefs discover the pioneering, independent cheese makers like Jasper Hill that broke new ground as they tore pages from European traditions. Her passing has resonated throughout the food world. “She was a humble and masterful advocate for American cheesemakers, fostering a deep appreciation for the craft and people behind the cheese,” said Adeline Druart, the president of Vermont Creamery. With Ms. Saxelby’s longtime business partner, Benoit Breal, now in charge, the company will continue its founder’s mission, “to be the bridge between local cheesemakers and the consumers for many years to come,” as Mr. Breal put it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: How to Prevent the Worst Case Extinction Scenario
description: People on both sides of the aisle can work together to prevent future calamities from unfolding.
content: NASHVILLE — If you’re a certain age, you may remember the snail darter, a small fish in the Little Tennessee River that caused an environmental firestorm when it was listed as endangered in 1975. At the time, the Tennessee Valley Authority was already in the midst of building a dam on the Little Tennessee. Snail darters require free-flowing water to reproduce, and the only known habitat for the entire species was about to be dammed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Alan Horn, a top creative executive, is the latest high-ranking Disney departure.
description: His retirement adds to brain drain at the world’s largest entertainment company as a new generation of executives rise to power.
content: One of Hollywood’s senior statesmen announced his retirement on Monday, adding to a startling changing of the guard at the Walt Disney Company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Florida City Sued Over Mural Depicting First Black Female Firefighter as White
description: Latosha Clemons, who rose to the rank of deputy fire chief in Boynton Beach, Fla., said the mural’s misrepresentation of her had caused her mental and emotional harm.
content: The city had never had a Black woman as a firefighter before Latosha Clemons, but last year when she glimpsed a publicly commissioned mural depicting her, she said, she didn’t recognize herself: She was white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Seeding Accounts for Kindergartners and Hoping to Grow College Graduates
description: New York City is giving every public school kindergartner $100 in a college savings account. Here’s why every penny matters.
content: Kindergarten often brings a flood of notices about events, school supplies and class photos. But when Vaniqua Hudson-Figueroa’s daughter started at a public school in Queens, there was one that Ms. Hudson-Figueroa wasn’t expecting: The city had opened a college savings account in her child’s name — and it already had $100 in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Matt Amodio’s ‘Jeopardy!’ Streak Ends After 38 Wins
description: The computer science Ph.D. student had the second-longest winning streak in the history of the game show.
content: Ken Jennings can relax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Election Workers in Georgia Are Fired for Shredding Voter Registration Forms
description: The office was already under fire from Trump supporters, who passed sweeping legislation that could lead to a takeover by the Republican-controlled State Legislature.
content: The elections office in Georgia’s heavily Democratic Fulton County said on Monday that two workers had been fired for shredding voter registration forms, most likely adding fuel to a Republican-led investigation of the office that critics call politically motivated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Returns to No. 1 With Autographed ‘Fearless’ CDs
description: The singer-songwriter’s “Fearless (Taylor’s Version),” the rerecorded edition of her breakthrough 2008 LP, surged to the top of Billboard’s album chart.
content: Streaming is everything in music today. But a pile of CDs, a marker and some elbow grease can still take you to No. 1 (at least if your name is Taylor Swift).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Chaos on Rikers Island
description: The jail complex is overrun by lawlessness, and the detainees are in control, a New York Times investigation found.
content: It’s Monday. We’ll look at the chaos inside the jail complex on Rikers Island. Scroll down and we’ll also look at a privately run park in Little Italy that the city wants to evict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner
title: Agony and Ecstasy on the Scottish Archipelago of St. Kilda
description: The 85-mile boat ride through rough seas left some of us huddling in discomfort. But the scenery on the remote and windswept islands was otherworldly.
content: For the first hour or so, the water was relatively calm. After departing from the small fishing village of Stein on the Isle of Skye, we sped through a strait known as the Little Minch toward the main band of the Outer Hebrides, the thick curl of rocky skerries that hovers like an apostrophe over the northwestern coast of mainland Scotland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Gin With a Hint of Mangosteen
description: Song Cai distills two gins in Hanoi, Vietnam. Try the dry version in a martini and sip the floral on the rocks.
content: Gin knows no boundaries. From its beginnings centuries ago, it has become a worldwide spirit distinguished by the presence of juniper. A new entry in the category — now riding a wave of popularity — is from Hanoi, Vietnam, with two gins bearing the Song Cai label. Each displays a different flavor profile; both are distilled with native botanicals foraged by families in rural communities that in turn receive support from the company. Only the necessary juniper is imported. Vietnam Dry Gin, clean and lively on the palate, with a hint of lime leaf dancing with juniper, will flatter your martini. Vietnam Floral Gin, fragrant and richly endowed with notes of mangosteen, cardamom and citrus, deserves to be sipped on the rocks. Each is 90 proof. The gins have been made since 2018, but are only now available in the U.S.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Shaxson
title: The City of London Is Hiding the World’s Stolen Money
description: Together with its territories overseas, Britain is instrumental in a global game of deceit.
content: In 1969, two years after the Cayman Islands, a British territory, passed its first law to allow secretive offshore trusts, an official government report struck an ominous note. A tide of glossy propositions from private developers, it warned, was washing through the islands. Cayman was fast becoming a state captured by shady finance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: White Tiger and Cheetah Furs: A Mess of Trump Gift Exchanges
description: Gift exchanges between U.S. and foreign leaders, a highly regulated process, devolved into sometimes risible shambles during the Trump administration.
content: The Saudi royal family showered Donald J. Trump and his entourage on his first trip abroad as president with dozens of presents, including three robes made with white tiger and cheetah fur, and a dagger with a handle that appeared to be ivory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Two Singers Reveal the Core of Art Song, on Stages Big and Small
description: This weekend, Jonas Kaufmann gave a recital at the vast Carnegie Hall, while Will Liverman appeared at the intimate Park Avenue Armory.
content: Two recitals over the weekend in New York might have seemed, at first, to inhabit very different realms of art song.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Home Sweet Home’ and ‘Succession’
description: A new series from Ava DuVernay debuts on NBC. And the third season of “Succession” begins on HBO.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 11-17. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Who Killed African Icon Thomas Sankara? Trial Opens, 34 Years After His Death.
description: The president of the West African nation of Burkina Faso, an anticolonial leader celebrated across the continent, was assassinated in 1987. Now 14 men, including the president who took his place, are on trial.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — One of the most highly anticipated trials ever to take place in Africa opened on Monday in the capital of Burkina Faso, aiming to establish who killed Thomas Sankara, the country’s former president and a revolutionary leader renowned across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman, Alexandra E. Petri and Victor Mather
title: After a Long Wait, the Boston Marathon Returns as a Fall Classic
description: More than two years after the last race, runners finally hit the pavement on Monday. “It just feels so good to be out here doing this,” one said.
content: BOSTON — After running more than 26 miles through the streets of greater Boston on Monday, Edna Havlin, a marathoner from Brazil, threw her arms up as she crossed the finish line. “We’re back!” she shouted as spectators cheered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Nobel in economics goes to three who find experiments in real life.
description: David Card, Joshua Angrist and Guido Imbens were honored for delving into cause and effect in ways that shed light on labor markets.
content: David Card has made a career of studying unintended experiments to examine economic questions — like whether raising the minimum wage causes people to lose jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 11, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 11, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Is China’s Soccer Boom Going Bust?
description: Chinese teams once embraced ambition and overspending in a bold attempt to reshape their sport. Now they don’t even play games.
content: The emails and letters complaining about unpaid salaries have been stacking up for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Johnson, Diana Nguyen, Sydney Harper, Dave Shaw, Marc Georges, Claudine Ebeid, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Which Towns Are Worth Saving?
description: How the climate crisis is forcing Americans to ask a difficult question.
content: The extreme weather and rising seas caused by the climate crisis are driving home an increasingly urgent lesson in the United States: An enormous infusion of money and effort will be needed to get ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Fuel for the Tailgate
description: Tropicoal Ignition burns hotter than regular charcoal briquettes and is made from discarded pieces of coconut, palm kernel and cassava.
content: Yes, it’s no longer summer grilling season. But how about tailgating or lighting the grill in the glow of early autumn with a new fuel? Agricycle, a company that repurposes agricultural waste, has introduced Tropicoal Ignition, effective charcoal briquettes for grilling that are made by smallholder farmers and women- and youth-led cooperatives throughout Africa from discarded coconut shells, palm kernel shells and cassava starch. The briquettes are completely natural, have no chemical ingredients and burn hotter than charcoals made of wood to quickly and cleanly sear those pork chops or slabs of eggplant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariella Rudi
title: ‘My Dinner With André’ at 40: Still Serving Hot Takes
description: The film was a feature-length conversation. And it is still stirring up plenty of chatter today.
content: Hear me out: “My Dinner With André” was the original podcast. Released on Oct. 11, 1981, this seminal art-house flick invited us to eavesdrop on 110-minutes of dialogue between two people who deliver hot takes and profundities that nobody asked for. And yet, “My Dinner With André” is just as fresh 40 years later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Racial Bias Skewed Small-Business Relief Lending, Study Says
description: Black business owners were more likely to get Paycheck Protection Program loans from online lenders than from banks, according to new research.
content: From the very start of the Paycheck Protection Program last year, it was clear that minority entrepreneurs, especially Black business owners, struggled more than white borrowers to find a willing lender. A new research project indicates that the problem was particularly pronounced at smaller banks — and human bias appears to be the main reason.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Finder
title: John le Carré’s Last Completed Spy Novel Crowns a Career Attuned to Moral Ambivalence
description: “Silverview” features a young bookstore owner in an English seaside town, caught up in an investigation involving two cunning spymasters.
content: SILVERVIEW By John le Carré
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Haven’t Watched ‘Squid Game’? Here’s What You’re Not Missing.
description: Beyond the memes, Netflix’s South Korean phenomenon doesn’t show or tell you anything you don’t already know. But it sure is bloody.
content: This notebook contains spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry and Alexandra E. Petri
title: In a first, the marathon begins with an acknowledgment of Indigenous land.
description: The focus on Indigenous peoples added an unusual, somber note to marathon weekend, in the heart of a region that has long unreservedly celebrated its colonial history.
content: It was well before dawn on Monday when, near the starting line of the 125th Boston Marathon, the chairman of the Boston Athletic Association read a statement acknowledging that the marathon’s 26.2 miles run through the homelands of Indigenous people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Roger Cohen
title: Clear Differences Remain Between France and U.S., French Minister Says
description: Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire says the two countries remain at odds over China and various security issues, even if they had effectively cooperated on overhauling the international tax system.
content: PARIS — As global finance leaders gather this week in Washington for the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund, Bruno Le Maire, the finance minister of France, made clear that effective French-American cooperation on an overhaul of the international tax system could not mask stark differences on China and other issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Guy Trebay
title: The End of Gender
description: Has fashion bid the binary goodbye?
content: One of the biggest trends of the spring 2022 fashion shows that just ended was not any particular silhouette or color, but rather the fact that many designers put both women and men on their runways in what once would have been termed “women’s wear” — not so much as provocation but simply as a matter of fact. Here, our two critics debate why, and what that may signify in terms of gender identity, sexuality and society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Pick a Card, Any Card, for Dinner Inspiration
description: Three students at the University of Pennsylvania have created Gourmand 52, a deck of playing cards that highlight a selection of New York restaurants.
content: Here’s a cunning little gift that gives back. Maggie Tang, Alaina Chou and Amy Yang, students at the University of Pennsylvania, have created a deck of cards with food illustrations from 52 New York restaurants. The selection includes Adda, Carbone, Don Angie, Katz’s Deli, Crown Shy, Olmsted and Via Carota. The project is supported by S. Pellegrino, Acqua Panna and Bentobox, and $3 of each deck will be donated to ROAR (Restaurants Organizing, Advocating & Rebuilding). It’s a project of Gourmand, an organization Ms. Tang and Ms. Chou founded to inspire an emerging generation of food lovers with events, podcasts and other features; it has spread to more than 10 campuses. The cards can be ordered starting Monday and will be delivered starting in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ashley Wu
title: Fighting the Dixie Fire
description: Inside the battle to defeat a wildfire the size of Rhode Island.
content: Wildfires have always been a normal part of life in the American West. During a typical year in the late 20th century, fires burned about 500,000 acres a year in California — an area equal to roughly half the size of Rhode Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Moderna sells its vaccine almost exclusively to wealthy countries.
content: Moderna has been supplying its coronavirus vaccine almost exclusively to wealthy nations, keeping poorer countries waiting while it earns billions in profit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo and Erin Griffith
title: Inside the Courtroom With Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes
description: Behind the closed doors are whispers, gestures and a daily rhythm, plus two court artists, numbered tickets and some true-crime fans.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Three days a week, Adriana Kratzmann, an administrator, opens the door at 8:30 a.m. to Courtroom 4 of the Robert F. Peckham Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Iohan Gueorguiev, ‘Bike Wanderer’ of the Wilderness, Dies at 33
description: He gained a following online for his lyrical appreciation of the open road while biking through remote landscapes and braving extreme conditions.
content: A truck barrels through a blizzard down a road made of ice. The road is so far north in Canada that at 10 p.m. the sun still illuminates the landscape, which is empty except for a few trees clinging to snow-covered hills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Canceled flights and train delays: We’re happy to have made it, some runners say.
description: Cancellations by Southwest and other airlines affected some Boston Marathon runners.
content: There’s not much the pandemic hasn’t delayed — Sunday travel to Boston was no exception. But some runners feared they might not make it at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Food Desk
title: The 2021 Restaurant List
description: The 50 places in America we’re most excited about right now.
content: The 50 places in America we’re most excited about right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Help Us Choose the Best Book
description: The New York Times Book Review has just turned 125. That got us wondering: What is the best book that was published during that time? We’d like to hear from you. For the month of October we’ll take nominations, in November we’ll ask you to vote on a list of finalists and in December we’ll share the winner.
content: The New York Times Book Review has just turned 125. That got us wondering: What is the best book that was published during that time? We’d like to hear from you. For the month of October we’ll take nominations, in November we’ll ask you to vote on a list of finalists and in December we’ll share the winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Sashwa Burrous, Eden Weingart and Meg Felling
title: Inside the Massive and Costly Fight Against the Dixie Fire
description: To battle the nearly one-million-acre Dixie fire, California launched a military-style operation. Some experts wonder whether that approach is sustainable.
content: To battle the nearly one-million-acre Dixie fire, California launched a military-style operation. Some experts wonder whether that approach is sustainable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yewande Komolafe
title: How to Make the Best Roasted Carrots
description: Yewande Komolafe shares a guide to making her new recipe featuring yaji spice, a mixture that's popular in West Africa.
content: Yewande Komolafe shares a guide to making her new recipe featuring yaji spice, a mixture that's popular in West Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.6 Million in California
description: A Spanish colonial-style retreat in Chico, a Mediterranean-style house in San Francisco and a three-bedroom home in Los Angeles.
content: A Spanish colonial-style retreat in Chico, a Mediterranean-style house in San Francisco and a three-bedroom home in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Dayton Police Department
title: Video Shows Police Pulling Man Out of Car by Hair During Traffic Stop
description: Police body camera footage showed officers in Dayton, Ohio, dragging Clifford Owensby out of his car as he yelled, “I’m paraplegic.” Mr. Owensby has filed a complaint with the N.A.A.C.P.
content: Police body camera footage showed officers in Dayton, Ohio, dragging Clifford Owensby out of his car as he yelled, “I’m paraplegic.” Mr. Owensby has filed a complaint with the N.A.A.C.P.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Nobel Prize in Economics Awarded to Three U.S.-Based Economists
description: The 2021 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences honored the work of David Card, Joshua Angrist and Guido Imbens, which changed the way that labor markets in particular are studied.
content: The 2021 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences honored the work of David Card, Joshua Angrist and Guido Imbens, which changed the way that labor markets in particular are studied.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Investing in the Future of Agriculture
description: Learn how Fidelity portfolio manager Steve Calhoun is investing in technologies that help drive innovation and productivity on the farm.
content: Learn how Fidelity portfolio manager Steve Calhoun is investing in technologies that help drive innovation and productivity on the farm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald, Elliot deBruyn and Meg Felling
title: ‘I’m Just Overjoyed’: Boston Marathon Racers Rejoice After Lost Year
description: Thousands of competitors ran the 2021 Boston Marathon. The prestigious race restarted this year after being canceled in 2020 because of the pandemic.
content: Thousands of competitors ran the 2021 Boston Marathon. The prestigious race restarted this year after being canceled in 2020 because of the pandemic.

title: The Temporary Truce on the Debt Ceiling

title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Greet the week with a comforting bowl of vegetarian tom yum soup with tofu.
content: Good morning. It is Columbus Day for some, Indigenous Peoples’ Day for others, Thanksgiving for Canadians and General Pulaski Memorial Day for those who remember the Polish hero of the American Revolution, who died after the siege of Savannah in 1779.
source.name: The New York Times
